content.description: There's some pretty thin, sketchy balance moves up on that ramp, just below the roof.
content.location: This is about where the trail dumps you out on the left side of the South Face.   R-L there is a somewhat prominent bolted overhang, a crack and a right-facing dihedral.  This  route is the crack.  (OH is Radical Bastard, dihedral is Irish Spring.)

content.description:
Basically the same as Dennis's

Corner Groveling

, but stick to the crack with gear and stop at the bolted anchor before heading out horizontal roof up top.

A large pod you can fit in, followed by being forced out of the crack, and some nice hands/thin hands to finish before stepping out to the anchors.

Single rack.  We placed a 5 and it was fine, but would have rather had a 6.
content.location: Starts under the large right arching dihedral near the center of the formation.  You can see this feature from the hike in.  This crack is in the back of the dihedral.  The guide book calls this the FM area.

content.description: Climb some blocks and fight a small tree - then delicate stepping up and right with a little overlap for help.  Eventually head straight up on easier slab.  Make a neat mantle at the roof and find some bolted anchors in front of you.
content.location: Tarzan wall, near the right but not thru the trees yet.  This follows the right most edge of the slab here for the first couple clips then heads up to the roof.  Tackles the roof without a crack - if there is a crack you are on one of the routes further left.

content.description: Short, but mostly fun.  Start up some easy slab (past a couple bolts).  Make the hardest move at ~15feet to get over a small step/roof and into a nice hand crack.  Follow this crack up on gear, then climb on top of some block up top to the bolted anchors.
content.protection: Bolts, light rack w/ hand sizes
content.location: On the ledge above and left of most of the other Visor Wall stuff.  Access by tunneling thru the trees from Tarzan wall stuff on the left, or climbing up to the ledge from the right.  Two routes with obvious bolts start from this ledge - this is the left most one.

content.description: Short.  Two clips past some lieback/pull left edge, zig zag right then left and reach up to the anchors.
content.location: Middle of the formation, before you hit the giant bolder and the FM area if traveling left to right.  Behind a large tree near the wall, and just to the right of Voodoo Cherry Bomb's start.

content.description: Clip a couple bolts trending right from the ledge, then up some overlaps past a couple more clips.  Finish on some featured face.
content.location: On the ledge above and left of most of the 'Visor Wall' stuff - you have to tunnel thru some trees to the right to get to the rest of the 'Tarzan Wall' climbs.  One of two routes accessed from this ledge - this is the one that heads out right.  New looking bolts - not the old hangers you can see further left which are part of Fox Trot

content.description: Climbs over the same visor roof the other routes do, but easier and just plain fun with big holds over the roof.
content.location: Walking west along the base of the south face, not far from where the trail comes up, there are several big rocks you have to climb over: look up and you'll see a crack and an eroded flake. That's the start of the route.

content.description:
Aside from one move getting over the roof on pitch 1, this is a nice 5.4-5.6 slab wander.  Take a couple pieces for second pitch if you want - we didn't use them.  Anchors are all bolted.

P1 - Up towards the left weakness in the roof band.  Or, up a bit right of this on "Red Line" if that looks more fun.  There are two bolted anchors 5 feet apart just above this roofline... pick one.

P2, P3 - Up.  Just go basically up on some nice mellow slab.  Start of pitch 2 you might want some gear (otherwise P2 only has 1 bolt), and you should have a right facing corner of semi broken rock just to your left.

P4 - gets real low angle here.  But... up and slight right and you will find another bolted anchor.

We linked 1 and 2, and 3 and 4 with a 60m.

Descent - rap the route.
content.protection: Bolts, a couple pieces for P2 possibly.
content.location: Stars near the lowest point of the slab on Tarzan wall.  You should be looking up at a roof line with two obvious weaknesses towards the left.  This is near the right side of the Tarzan wall, but on the far left of the formation.

content.description: Another fun face route with a lot of texture.  Collect the whole set.
content.location:
The trail comes up on the east edge of what the Laramie Range book calls the Visor Wall.

This route is near the west edge of this area.  You could easily throw a stone from Voodoo Cherry Bomb to here, so don't go much past the big rocks in the path at the base of the cliff.  If I recall correctly, this route starts in a hole between some rocks.

content.description: Thinning moves to the roof (Visor) and a heck of a step up balance move to get over it to the chains.
content.location:
I'd call this the left side of the south face, maybe still in the first quarter, left to right.  Orenczak & Lynn called this area the visor wall.  It's about where the trail dumps you out, so it isn't too hard to find.  Right facing dihedral was a bit wet down low.  There's 3 routes right here without moving the pack.

There is a variation below the overhang: keep heading right past a bolt, through a low spot in the roof and over to Voodoo Cherry Bomb. Orenczak & Lynn called it Hand From Above at 5.9+.

content.description:
Last route west on the "Visor Wall." (It's only about 15 feet further west to the next "Tarzan Wall" route.)  Anyhow, this route is old style, but with beefy pro; the first 2 hangers look like big pound-ins, the next 5 are homemade angle iron hangers with 3/8" bolts. (If you have way beefy 'biners, they may not fit easily through the holes.)  P1 zigzags for about 95 feet to cold shuts.  I'm sure most folks rap off here.

If you do the second pitch, a light rack may help, but not much.  There's another angle-iron bolt hanger and a bent piton on the way to running out the entire 70m along moderate terrain.

We walked maybe 40 feet west on the ledge to the top of Moorcroft City Slicker and did 4 raps down w 1 rope.
content.protection: 7 clips to the cold shuts.  Light rack if you go all the way.

content.description: Foxy Dance is a sustained micro edge crimper climb without rests but good pro.
content.location: The route begins about 12 feet to the right of the prominent dihederal corner with seemingly no comfortable belay location.

content.description: Corner Groveling is a steepish slab climb that makes use of the left side of the dihederal when the edges get to small for peddling your feet.
content.location: This route begins at the base of the major dihederal at the base of the south face.

content.description: The Belgium Chocolate Waltz is a climb here that makes use of the irregularities from what would be on a slab route.  Yes, its a pleasing zig zagging line the make use of the various small brownish corners and holds.
content.location: Find this route to the right of the steep slab zone which is to the right of the major dihereral.  The route begins near the right corner of a large boulder that covers the base of the slab.

climbs.name: Ancient History
climbs.fa: unknown -- an army ring angle piton was found on this line.

content.description: Ancient History was the route chosen BITD or at least attempted?  One rusted army ring angle piton was in the short crack down low.  The modernized sport route follows this short crack and continues up the slab until one can walk without using the hands.
content.location: Ancient History begins in a crack about 60 feet left of the major low dihederal on the south face.

pathTokens: Laramie Peak Wildlife Habitat Management Area
